title: Pen Casing w/ Screw on Cap

description.text: This is a casing for the inside of an already existing pen. The cap screws on to the body.

description.header: Project: Pen Casing w/ Screw on Cap
description.text:
Objectives This project teaches a lot about measuring and making a model that fits the measurements. It also gets you used to a lot of extrusions. Audiences This project does not need too much skill. A beginner to intermediate designer could draw this. Preparation This project was done on Inventor, and to print it, a 3D printer is required. A basic knowledge of Inventor or a similar software is needed. Steps! The pen body is just a tube with threads attached to it on the inside ends and the outside.
The tip is just a cone shape with the inside hollowed out and a hollow cylinder with threads so it can be screwed on.
The end is a cylinder with a rounded top and hollow cylinder with threads so it can be screwed on.
The cap is a hollow cylinder with a rounded end and a threaded inside to screw it onto the body. Results You should have a great pen with a screw on cap at the end!

title: Lost in Space B9 Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my rendition of the Lost in Space B9 Robot.
All files are manifold and print well on the Makerbot Replicator Mini.
The biggest problem with any B9 model is the globe. Here, I had used a 50c gumball container cut in half. Please, if anyone has a better solution then post it. The only parts that need support when printing is the neck, Body middle and claws. The area under the talking plate is hollow and there is a passage between that hollow area and the main body if anyone wanted to install lights and batteries.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes: The white,gray and black in the THING file names is a filament color suggestion.

The plastic parts come off shiny which is -not- how it should look. I had airbrushed the gray, black and other colors using Liquitex acrylic heavy body paint. Then the non-black parts were followed up with airbrushed Miniwax Polycrylic (Non-yellowing water based polyurethane) for a satin finish. I did not use the polyurethane on the black parts so they keep the rubberish textures. I glued it all together with JB weld epoxy.
Some parts will need light sanding for a proper fit before gluing.
Enjoy
I used NewTek's Lightwave 3d for CAD and referenced various sources for dimensions.

DNA / RNA manipulative remix This was designed from the original files in TinkerCAD.I put 2 3 mm holes though the pieces to provide a way to string them all together. The set pictured is the prototype,but you should print them in contrasting colors.

Project: Display DNA / RNA sequence For this project, I wanted a way to display a students DNA / RNA sequence for science fairs or presentations. By putting holes through the pieces, students can string them together for a science fair project or presentation. Objectives Students demonstrate their understanding of DNA, RNA, and genetics.
Students produce a model to demonstrate scientific knowledge for public presentation.
Students presents a professional presentation for a varied audience.
Students presents genetic research to a professional audience. Audiences High School biology, AP bio, College biology, College genetics, genetic councilors and medical professionals. Preparation Students should understand DNA/ RNA, and genetics.
Students should prepare their research, and plan out how to model it with this set.
Students should 3Dprint enough base pairs to meet their display needs. Steps This set can be used as a display piece for genetic research.
After conducting your research, use this set to produce a physical model for presentations. Use this set to demonstrate restriction enzymes, cleavage sites, and DNA sequences involved in research. Results As a result of this, you should have a product you can take to professional conferences and science presentations. The public can inspect your work and model to see the DNA sequence you are working with.

title: 110 Film Holder for Plustek OpticFilm Scanner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you still have some strips of 110 film that were used in pocket cameras back in the 1970s and 1980s? And do you have a Plustek OpticFilm scanner?
This is a film holder for 110 films. Just place the film strip into the holder, put the cover on the holder, and scan the film. There is a solid version, and a light version with struts that saves a little material. With the customizer, you can also choose the number of windows.
I recommend to use black filament, to reduce scatter lights from the scanner lamp while scanning.

Actually, I am not completely happy with the result. The film strip shifts in the holder, I probably should have added some registration pins to hold it in place. Also the notches on the edges of the holder seem to be a little too wide. The holder is not fixed exactly in the center of the frame, so each scan may need some minor position readjustments. I also had some issues with pillowing. I first used an infill of 20%, with poor results. For the prints on the photos, I used a 24% infill, which was acceptable. I only had a small number of film strips to scan, and the holder did a good job. However, for a larger number you may want to do some minor improvements. The SCAD source code is included, so feel free to make a remix.

THIS THING IS NOT INTENDED TO BE PRINTED. IT HAS NO INHERENT PURPOSE. In fact, the "thing" I'm highlighting here is the negative space created in this rectangular prism. The photographs are of similar sized and spaced holes created in other projects of mine. The three holes in this block are the measurements I've found work well when printed through a Replicator 5th Generation for mounting VEX EDR motors and servos, both 2-wire and 3-wire, to anything. The slight depressions on either side of the mounting screw holes make it so that the motor and the screw head recess into the block. I've used these measurements in all of my VEX Robotics projects since figuring them out as one of my very first SketchUp practice projects.

title: Y-Axis Back Plate Assembly for MakerFarm 8", 10" or 12" Prusa i3v

description.text:
Updated Dimension Image
I updated the image showing the dimensions for the different i3v sizes. The dimension variables are in blue & the differences between the different sizes are shown. This is an assembly of parts to replace all the wooden parts on the back of Y-axis of Makerfarm i3v printers. I made this to replace the wooden Y-Axis back plate on my 10" i3v, but made versions for the 8" & 12" also. The 10" version are from measurements I took with a digital caliper. The dimensions for the 8" I received from Colin Farrer & the 12" dimensions came from the dxf file located here: https://github.com/DonKahones/MakerFarm-Prusa-i3v-12-Inch These parts consist of a left & right side back plate, a back brace on the back, curved plate on the front & 2 peg hole fillers. This does not use nut traps like the wooden part, but instead slides over each side. You will need to change the 2-M5x12mm bolts to 2-M5x20mm bolts to connect the V-Slot. You will also had to use 4-M3x20mm socket head bolts on each side to connect to the left & right frame. For the back brace & curved plate you will need 5-M5x20mm for the 5 bolt holes where both brackets connect & 1-M5x14mm bolt to connect back brace to the Back Plate to the right of the motor. The attached photos should show you how all this connects. I included test files for you to print 1st to make sure everything lines up correctly on your machine. I would print the TopSideTest file for your machine 1st, then overlay it on top of the back pate to make sure it all lines up. The Top side files for those are:
Y-AxisBackPlate_8_TopSideTest_Rev38_repaired.stl
Y-AxisBackPlate_10_TopSideTest_Rev38_repaired.stl
Y-AxisBackPlate_12_TopSideTest_Rev38_repaired.stl The vertical Test files will show you whether all the bolt holes heat bed bolt cutouts line up correctly. The heat bed bolt cutout for the 8", I did not get the dimension for, so that is one to be sure & check if you are using an 8" i3v. The bolt holes for the test prints are sized for the bolt head diameter so these test parts should be flush with the wood if they match. The Vertical Test files are:
Y-AxisBackPlate_8_VerticalTest_Rev38_repaired.stl
Y-AxisBackPlate_10_VerticalTest_Rev38_repaired.stl
Y-AxisBackPlate_12_VerticalTest_Rev38_repaired.stl The final files to print for the 10" i3v are:
Y-AxisBackPlate_10_LeftSide_Rev38_repaired.stl
Y-AxisBackPlate_10_RightSide_Rev38_repaired.stl
i3v_Y_10inchOblongBackBrace_Rev38_repaired.stl
i3v_Y_10inchCurvedPlate_Rev38_repaired.stl
PegHoleFill_Rev4_repaired.stl For the 8" or 12" use the 4 parts that have those numbers in the name. You can also change the openscad files to your liking. Those with 12" version may want to make the OblongBackBrace taller for more support. The assembly on the 10" i3v is pretty stiff. The variable to change this height in the i3v_Y_OblongBackBrace_Rev38.scad file is:
Ldg_Taper_Ht = 14; //Height of Ledge. The longest print will be the right side, which took me 9 hours to print for the 10" i3v. The total print time I had for all the parts was 16:56:43 & 6.53oz of PETG plastic. I printed these with 50% 3d honeycomb infill. For the top & bottom I used Octagram Spiral which makes the part look kind of cool. I used DXF files in conjunction with the openscad files. There is one DXF for each i3v version & you can change some of the cutouts there if you do not like the cutouts I used. I put an f cut on each side which is similar to that used on a violin or cello. I thought that might help dissipate some vibration, but mostly to just look unique. The printer does have a more muted sound when the Y-axis is moving now. That is probably more to do with changing the wood to plastic than the hole patterns. The 8" version did not have room for that f cutout on the right side. The variables to change in the Y-AxisBackPlate_Rev.scad file for your specific machine are:
i3v = 10;
i3v_Width = 297; //10" i3v
i3v_Vslot_Width = 189.58; //10" i3v
i3v_Vslot_Offset = 62.9; //10" i3v
i3v_MotorOffset = 141.0; //10" i3v In case you need to change the Heat bed Slot dimensions for an 8" i3v. These numbers seem to be the same for the 10" & 12", but maybe different for the 8". These dimensions are measured from the center of the V-Slot to the Left side of the rectangle slot cut:
HB_Slot_Left = 36.2; //This is the Negative Number
HB_Slot_Right = 24; //This is the Positive Number
HB_Slot_Ht = 6; //Usually 6, but useful to change if printing Test bracket tops The peghole fill stl file I made with several tolerances from 0 to .3mm clearance. I then used the peg hole fill parts that fit the best in the 6x10mm peg holes. I initially made 3 holes on each side, but it seemed that 2 bolts were enough to hold it in place. In the openscad file for Oblong & Curved part, you only need to change the i3v variable to the version you are using. When installing this assembly, I would assembly the Left, Right Back Plates with the oblong & curved brackets before detaching your wooden plate. You might also want to install the motor on the plastic part before attaching it to the frame. After you take off your back wooden plate, install the peg hole inserts in the bottom peg holes on left & right side vertical wood frame. To make sure your M3 holes are lined up, insert your allen wrench thru the hole to make sure it they line up. When bolting on the V-Slot, sight thru the plastic hole to line up the M5 hole in the V-Slot. That helped me to bolt it on easily. It was a little bit of effort to make this for all 3 versions. I have verified this as best I can, but I could have missed something. Let me know you have any problems with these parts.

The underplate just clips on. It still allows airflow over the PDB while protecting it. It's 1mm bigger than the pdb in every direction.
You can land on the underplate since there are little ledges at each corner under the clips to securely hold it in place while still being easy to remove.

The "gloves" are completely inside the dimensions of the "hands" at the ends of the arms so no thrust from the props is blocked or wasted. The recessed holes are set such that they act as clips to hold the gloves on. You don't need to unbolt the motors or find longer screws.
I've also put 1 tiny spot of superglue on each so that i can still easily get them back off again but this is optional. The clip idea alone is not super secure, fine for gentle use only.
I have the openscad files on my github: https://github.com/CraigJPerry/Nighthawk280ProtectionKit

No

No

2mm

20%

Notes: I use a 2mm layerheight & 20% infill in both HIPS and ABS. HIPS is slightly lighter, ABS is slightly stronger but HIPS is stronger than needed here anyway. I used 1mm wall width (i have a 0.5mm nozzle) and i used 1mm top and bottom. I feel these are excessive, when re-printing i will turn these settings down. Might save 2-3g. The USB hole in the underplate does NOT require support, at least on a lulzbot mini.
See the comments in the OpenSCAD files. This was my first OpenSCAD project.

title: XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro E3D V6 Drop-In Cartridge Mount

description.text:
This thing makes it easier to install an E3D V6 hot end in a XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro printer by merely unclamping/unplugging the stock extruder module, transferring the PCB and fan from the stock extruder cartridge to this thing, assembling the E3D V6 with the heater cartridge and thermistor from the stock extruder, mounting the E3D V6 hot end in this thing and then plugging/clamping this thing into the daVinci Pro in place of the stock extruder module.
Note that this design is specific to the E3D V6's dimensions.  I have a hot end that purports to be an E3D V6 clone, but other than the mounting collar at the top the dimensions are all off. The overall height is about a centimeter more which is really too much to use with this configuration -- of course, I suppose you could make an extension for the Z-axis stop flag and just remember that you're z-axis print volume will be a bit less. However, the heatsink diameter is also a couple of millimeters larger which get's pretty tight in the Pro's carriage.

If you are interested in purchasing this thing pre-printed, it is available from PrintIt Industries at: http://www.printitindustries.com/collections/featured-products/products/e3d-mount-for-xyz-davinci-pro You will still need to provide the hot end, fan, PCB and assembly hardware.

I sell fully assembled and tested replacement cartridges made with genuine E3D V6 hot end components for 150USD plus shipping. I can also make the cartridge with E3D's Lite6 hot end for 120USD if the Lite6 hot end fits your needs. I usually need 7-10 days lead time to assemble and test a cartridge before shipping. If you are interested in an assembled cartridge, message me here on Thingiverse for details. If you prefer to pay for the convenience of ordering right now, you can also look to see if I have any cartridges available in my Tindie store:

I also sell just my replacement PCB for the hot end cartridge for 50USD plus shipping. If you are interested in ordering a PCB, message me here on Thingiverse for details. If you prefer to pay for the convenience of ordering right now, you can also look to see if I have any PCBs available in my Tindie store:

Printer:

da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height / 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

15% Honeycomb

Notes: Material: ABS (Brand: CEL Robox, Color: Red)
Extruder Temp: 228C
Bed Temp: 85C For the main cartridge body I printed it flat on its back w/ brim and supports (standard density). You'll need to clear supports from:
  • The M3 nut cavities on the back (if using nuts to secure PCB)
  • The small holes on the bottom that engage the studs in the printer's carriage.
  • The holes on the top that are engaged by the studs in the printer's carriage clamp.
  • The side openings that provide access to the PCB connections.
    • NOTE: If you can bridge fairly well, then the cartridge body can actually be printed without supports. This may also require a small bit of clean-up at the bridged sites, but still produces a nice cartridge. The cartridges I get from PrintIt industries are done without supports and work very well. The clamp and fan shroud I printed with brim but without any supports. The clamp should be printed with the part that holds the heat sink facing up. The fan shroud should be printed with the side that mates to the main cartridge down.

After printing you may need to sand the back of the main cartridge and the side of the fan shroud that mounts to it. Then you'll need to assemble with appropriate hardware. PCB
I used M3x12mm machine screws and M3 nuts for mounting the PCB. FAN SHROUD
For mounting the fan shroud I used #6 x 1/4" screws made for plastic and Gorilla Glue; I applied a very small bead of glue just around the air path then screwed the shroud to the main body and clamped together until cured. FAN
To mount the fan to the fan shroud I used #4 x 3/4" screws made for plastic or these phillips ones and #4 washers from Home Depot. HEATSINK CLAMP
To secure the heatsink clamp to the main body I used the same #4 x 3/4" screws or or these and #4 washers I used for mounting the fan. ADDITIONAL NOTES
When you mount the E3D V6 hot end into the cartridge be sure to route the heater and thermistor wires so that they go behind the cartridge and run up next to the fan shroud. If you try to put the cartridge into the printer with the wires running up the side of the main body it won't fit into the carriage properly. The nozzle on this will sit quite a bit lower than the stock nozzle. I had to bump my z-offset to about 8.5mm (from about 0.6mm on the stock nozzle), but I didn't have to re-level my bed. You could also make the adjustment by cranking the bed leveling screws tighter, -- in fact, if you wind up needing more than the 9mm max z-offset you'll need to adjust using the bed levelers.

2016/03/09 As I was preparing to print v1.5 of the main body today I noticed there were some parts near the bottom that should have been trimmed off. I have updated the STL file for v1.5. 2016/02/26 I uploaded a new version of the main body (v1.5). This one brings a shroud in around the heat sink more like the fan shroud that comes with the E3D V6 kit. I have not yet had a chance to print and test fit this model, yet. If someone else wants to print it and let me know how it works, go for it. 2016/02/23 FINALLY! Last night I screwed/glued the fan shroud onto the cartridge body and let it cure overnight. This morning I assembled the rest of the pieces (the pictures have been updated to the ones from this latest build). This one fits into the printer and prints well. After saving this update I will update my print settings with what I used, but each of you probably have a better idea what settings work best for your printer/filament. If anyone runs into problems using this design please leave a comment. There may still be some tweaks needed to ensure it will work for everyone. To see a video of this thing in action click https://youtu.be/srfnkiDOFgI 2016/02/22 VERY CLOSE NOW! Yesterday I thought I had my design finalized, but after assembling it I found it wouldn't fit into the printer because the PCB was mounted about 1.5-2mm too high and the filament sensor/guide wasn't clearing the filament "funnel" on the carriage. So, back to 123D Design and I lowered the screw holes for the PCB, and also lowered where the heatsink mount is a bit. Last night I printed what I thought was the final version; unfortunately, when I was assembling it today I found not enough clearance between the PCB and the top of the heatsink. With a little persuasion I got things put together, but with everything so tight I found the filament just didn't want to make the transition from the sensor guide into the top of the heat sink (actually, into the short piece of copper tubing I'm using to help guide the filament into the heat break). With enough pressure it would go, but I didn't want to introduce that strain to the Bowden feed system. Today I made some additional adjustments and re-printed. I just test-mounted the heatsink and PCB into the latest print, and the fit is good. Tomorrow I will finish assembling the full drop-in cartridge, ensure it fits into the carriage properly and print with it. I have updated the STL files to the latest versions, but be warned they are not fully tested, yet. 2016/02/18 The design is almost ready for primetime. I printed my most recent design today, and assembled my E3D V6 with it. Fit is good. I am using a clone PCB I soldered up, and I need to print a filament guide to go over my filament sensor and guide the filament through the middle of the sensor and into the heat sink. 2016/02/17 I have been making lots of tweaks to my design. I have separated the fan shroud out to a separate piece to be glued/screwed to the main body. This simplifies printing the pieces without excessive supports. I have also extended the bottom of the main body to provide more airflow to the heat sink.

comments.text: Have you determined if the filament is getting hung up in the carriage, in the cartridge, or between the carriage and the cartridge? For example, if you have no cartridge installed, can you feed the filament all the way through such that it is coming out at the carriage end? If so, with the cartridge in place, if you feed the filament in until it gets stuck can you easily remove the cartridge at that point? If so, you probably have an alignment problem between the metal funnel in the carriage and the black filament guide/sensor on the PCB. If you can't easily remove the cartridge there may be an alignment between the PCB and the hot end. With the cartridge outside of the printer can you easily feed filament through the PCB sensor and into the heat sink?

comments.text: Hi Oscar, What sort of oozing are you seeing? I print primarily in ABS with retraction of ~5mm-5.6mm, and other than the filament that leaks out of the nozzle during heating and cooling I don't have any oozing problems. When I occassionally print PLA I still get a fair amount of stringing. I think this is because I am afraid to set my retraction higher than ~4.5mm for fear of filament clogging my heat break. I don't have enough experience printing PLA to really know what I can get away with, and I have found different PLAs can make a difference in how likely they are to build up and get stuck in the heat break.

comments.text: So, Does having the fan up there in that angle improves air flow? I'm curious about how this design compares to using the stock E3D V6 Fan Duct and running wires for the 12 V fan, have you had any problems related to a non properly cooled heat sink?
comments.author: subscor

comments.text: I have not done any scientific analysis of the airflow, but by placing the fan at an angle the airflow is more directly pointed at the E3D heatsink. Because of how low in the cartridge/carriage the heatsink sits a vertically mounted fan would have a very disrupted path to the heatsink. The airflow path to the bottom fins of the heatsink is very narrow so I tried to make the path as direct as possible.
comments.author: subscor

I still have it, but just haven't had the time to reconfigure the printer with it and test it again.

comments.text: Would this work with a 1.0a? Seems to be the same drive types.
comments.author: fencing49

comments.text: I believe the 1.0a uses a direct drive system with the extruder feeder motor mounted on the print carriage whereas the 1.0 Pro has a Bowden feed system with the feeder motor mounted at the back of the printer pushing the filament through a tube to the hot end.  Because of this, I don't think this mount leaves enough room for the filament feeder gears on the 1.0a.  I also don't know if the extruder cartridge dimensions on the 1.0a match the 1,0 Pro or not.

description.text: I bought a vintage Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Turtlecycle (Circa 1989) that was missing basically everything. No side car, no handle bars, no headlight, no accessories. It was very cheap, and I figured I could piece it together eventually. I cannot find the headlights anywhere... so I made one to print. It is different than the original, but matches the bike's style nicely. The fit is very snug and you will not need glue. Print in orange, black or green to match the bike. If you make one let me know. I'd love to see it on your bike The handlebars with the grips on the main photo are the ones I use with this bike. I printed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:942724 by gettinnerdy in PLA and scaled them down to 22.5%. I realize that, because the peg on the bike is angled up, the head light is angled up. I will be working on angling the cut out so that the light is level, but I am new to making 3D images and haven't figured that part out yet. The cut out for the peg is not centered. I purposefully put it closer to the top so that the light would sit lower on the bike.

Yes

I really love to build space ships and space shuttles - and sometimes draw them. With the help of the 3D software available, my chances of making such things has increased. I built this project out of a images I saw in NASA's website and decided to share it with others so that other people can enjoy using these things...

Step 1 In this project (i.e. the space shuttle), I started to see close-up images of the space shuttle Google Images - Space Shuttles Google Images - Space Shuttle Design Step 2 Use a 3D Designing software (I used 123D Design). Insert 4 cylinders (i.e. 3 cylinders for the booster rockets and one for the shuttle itself). Consider the proportions. Use the Chamfer and Fillet options to sharpen the points. Step 3 Add details by using Polyline (i.e. you can split solids and add more details to it). Step 4 Merge the solids together and print it [if possible]. Enjoy your very own-made Space Shuttle... Requirements Nothing is needed but a creative mind and a computer - works best if your computer is powerful. You need to download one of the 3D software (i.e. 123D Design) or use the online ones (which are much easier to utilize) as that of Tinkercad...

Objectives I was inspired by many people - including my teacher to create 3D models. I decided to create a 3D model as simple as it is and transfer this notion of creativity and love of art to others. Audiences Skills: simple computer skills and familiarity with the 3D printing and 3D printing software.
Grades: 5 - 12+
Ages: 8 - 99+
Side Note: Younger people might not be able to work with 3D designing software, hence choosing the age category and grades as high as grade 5 and 8 years. Preparation Check out the following links before starting this project to get an overview of how to work with 123D Design easily (YouTube Videos): i. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8nEzlY4i3aQ
ii. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QZxsLNvlcY
iii. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cPGDQ68SgMY
iv. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_dlGox0BxOY
v. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1QWALh4Jmt8 Side Note: learn more about Space Shuttles and how they work by going to NASA's (or ESA) websites. Project Idea Please refer to the “How I Designed This” section to get a brief summary of how to design this project. Results By the end of this project, you will have a space shuttle I designed by yourself. [if you can print the Space Shuttle], you will have your own space Shuttle and can place it on a flat surface (i.e. a table) or hang it from a wall.

title: HICTop 3dp-11 Z-axis top plate with bearing

description.text:
Not satisfied with the noise of the original part or the design of other created options I found, I designed this Z-axis top plate/bracket to improve it. It is simple and clean, and that is how I like it. The bearing is interference fit so it should not move. The bearing is a standard inexpensive skateboard bearing. Just press it into place and go. Note to those concerned about securing the threaded rod, it is not a tight fit at all within the inner race of the bearing. The hard steel of the inner sleeve does not squeak or even move as the x-axis move up and down. The bearing is essentially useless, but I guess it cannot ever bind because if it does then the bearing would work.
I created it in 123D Design and included the original file for reference. BTW: the holes lined up perfectly, so no concern there.

Printer:

HICTop 3dp-11

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40

Notes: A little elephant foot at the bottom of the bearing hole is not necessarily a problem. I would not clean that up.
Chased some holes with a drill bit to make the rods and screws fit, but otherwise nothing to worry about.
Knowing the parts were made to metric specs, I measure and defaulted to the nearest millimeter. It worked perfectly as I stated.

Features include:
  • Arduino controlled so it can blink in different speeds, colorfade, etc. AND you can reprogram it to make whatever you want.
  • Three pots to set the red, green and blue LEDs.
  • reprap printed knobs for the pots
  • Osram RGB LED (almost perfect point light source) with 30mA per color.
  • exchangable stencil
  • one rotating axis to project onto a wall or the ceiling.
    • more pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/wizard23/

cut the carlo-projector44_final export.dxf file for cutting. carlo-projector44_final.dxf  contains all the help lines and dimensions in case you want to modify the design. 
Most parts are cut from 1.5mm very stable cardboard. For the rotation mechanism the outer part is cut out of 2mm delrin and holds the inner part which is cut from cardboard. The inner part can rotate but only in discrete steps. it also gives a snapping sound :)
Most of the parts are fitted together with a cardboard snapping mechanism. some parts need to be screwed together with M3 nuts and bolts and youll need 2 about 12cm long M6 rods and some nuts for the base.
I also uploaded the Arduino source code. 
What I havent uploaded is the scematics for the electronics, but that was built on a stripboard so I don't have a digital design I could upload. But basically I connect the RGB led to some PWMs and 3 pots to analog ports. The code tells what pin to use.
I made a small mistake in the xxx_42 files, use the xxx_43 files

title: Simple Prusa i3 Filament Spool Holder. (Makerbot 2kg spools)

description.text:
This is a very simple but reliable filament holder for prusa i3, makerbot spools. I know this is pretty specific, but I thought I would at least share the idea so others can make their own for their particular spools. Notes:
Ultra-fast spool changing, Takes seconds!
Only 2 small pieces to print
Requires only 1 piece of additional hardware: 1 608 bearing Instructions:
  • Print both pieces.

    I had to print the bearing holder @ 102% size to get the fit I wanted but my printer was having a bad day. The spool pin was normal 100%.

  • Use channel-locks or similar tool to pop the bearing in.
  • Use channel locks or similar tool to push bearing holder into spool,

    You want to get the bearing near-flush with 1 side of the spool.

  • Remove the top screw and spacer from your LCD screen, of the side of your choice.
  • Slide the spool pin over the printer frame so that the holes line up with the screw you removed. And also so the thin 'leg' is in front.
  • Re-install screw without spacer.
  • Slide on spool with the bearing flush-side down.
  • Enjoy
  • Come back to thingiverse to leave comment

This is a sled designed to be placed at the end of a section of hotwheels track. The car rolls into the sled and then slides across the desk/floor. In my classroom I use this as part of our Work and Energy unit. I set up the track like a ramp do the car rolls down and into the sled. Students calculate the gravitational potential energy of the car at the top and measure the distance the sled slides. With this students can use conservation of energy to determine the work done by friction on the sled, then using the distance the sled slid they can find the force of friction on the sled, and even the coefficient of friction.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3 no need for high res

Infill:

variable. I like 10%

Notes: No need to run this on high resolution settings, .3 layer height and low infill is just fine. If you are not having problems with adhesion, no need for a raft, this has a nice wide flat base to stick to the platform.

Designing more Autodesk Inventor is a free 3 year license for students or teachers and is great for 3D design. I sized this one to fit the end of the track and cars that we use in out classroom, but feel free to scale or modify to fit your needs. Scaling up and down could also make a great lesson in the impact of surface area on friction (or lack there of)

description.header: Project: Work done by Friction Physics Lab
description.text: Objectives Students will be able to determine the relationship between potential energy and work done by friction. Students will be able to apply Newton's Laws and friction equations to the concept of energy conservation to determine the coefficient of friction. Audiences Great for 9-12 physics or physical science students studying work and energy. Could also be used in elementary to develop a more qualitative understanding of why the car will slide further when released from a greater height. Preparation This project also needs hot wheels cars and track or similar. Could be done with rolling a ball or firing a rubber band also. Ideal students would already be familiar with newtons laws, energy transfers and friction. To set up the experiment set a length of track against a wall or propped up on books. Secure the track with tape so it doesn't fall and set the sled at the end of the track. Students will need a measuring device like a meter stick or tape measure. Steps In the thing files you will find the Lab Activity sheet I had out with this lab. Feel free to message me if you would like a word doc version of the sheet so you can modify it. The step by step for the students is all there, you just need to get everything set up and help guide them through! Results By the end of this lab students should have a better grasp on application of work/energy and newtons laws. The connection should be clear. A great extension of this assignment would be to have each group design or modify a new sled to see how it changes the results. I think learning activities like this are important for students to be able to explore. For grading I use a stamping method for completion. Stamp = full credit. We want them to learn and explore, not nitpick points!

author: Hyas

title: K8200/3Drag ZAxis with one M8 and one M5 mandrels

description.text:
The problem of the K8200 is, if you resolve a problem, you get focused on another one.
But I like to improve my printer.
My last project is nearly finished, so I started my work on a new Z-axis modification. My problem is, I don't have much money at the moment, so I decided to use M5 mandrels cause I have enough 5mm ball bearings. I hope that I can show you some pictures of the working modification at the end of the week. If there are any good ideas out in the Thingivers, feel free to comment! Thank you for your interest. There is a new modified X axis drive which you can use seperatly. The belt is now below of the slide. It is important to change the direction of the X axis in firmware. I haven't drawn a new holder for the endstop yet, I just improvised a little bit. The modified Z drive on the right side must be used completly because the distance to the aluminium profile has changed.

February 12th.: Just made my first test with this construction. Doesn't work yet. But I found a lot of solutions to make it doing what I want. February 13th: I changed some thngs. I will keep the original M8 mandrel on the left side and add two M5 mandrels on the right side. The M8 drive works really fine without the others. But I think with the M5 madrels it will be nicer. I will use a pulley with 25 teeth on the left side and two pulleys with 16 teeth on the right side. February 18th: As I noticed that two mandrels on one side make more problems than advantages, I decided to reduce to a single M5 mandrel on the right side. So it is working for the first time. But there are still many things to improve.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ez_DNxJFaU0 One big problem I have at the moment is a very high temperature in the housing of the printer. All PLA parts I was printing before break now. That's the reason why there is so much tape in the printer. But the printing quality is much better with a case.

Parametric Lego Omni-Ball. This design is inspired by the Omni-Ball design of Osaka University. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BTp2UAaihaI The Osaka University design has been converted into a model that can be build with Lego Mindstorms. For assembly instructions of the Omni-Ball see the photo's. To build a single Omni-Ball following items are required:
  • OmniBall.stl (2x)
  • CenterPieceTop.stl (1x)
  • CenterPieceBottom.stl (1x)
  • Lego Axle 12L, Part No 3708 (1x)
  • Lego Axle 8L with stop, Part No 55013 (1x)
  • Lego Pin, Part No 2780 (4x)
  • Lego Bushing, Part No 4265a (4x)
    • As center piece several options are possible:
  • use CenterPiece.stl (will be extremely hard to print; so not recommended)
  • use CenterPieceTop.stl and CenterPieceBottom.stl (easy to print,as specified in the part list above)
  • use CenterPieceRight.stl (easiest to print; mechanically not perfect, but will just work fine)
    • Remark:
  • No support structures are required.
    • The Omni-Balls in action:
    https://youtu.be/ZOCdI2gzMqI

Working but work-in-progress solder paste extruder. This is part of the BambiPNP pick-and-place system for the Replicator 1 Dual and clones. Design requirements were:
  • 3d printing only (no laser cutting etc)
  • Good tolerance of low resolution printer
  • Few non-printed parts
    • The only non-printed parts required are:
  • Nema 17 stepper motor
  • 3x 100mm M6 roofing bolts
  • 5x M6 roofing bolt nuts
  • Standard 10cc syringes
    • It seems the nuts and bolts used are only common in the UK (although international shipping is free). TODO:
  • Add carriage mount
  • Move stepper down so cable doesn't clash with printer case
  • Adjust to take an XG Z40 syringe
  • Adjust to use more standard 100mm M6 hex bolts?

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: The only part that needs support is gear1.stl.

Instructions
  • Place one bolt, pointing upward, into each of the slots on the top of the body and fix in place with a nut.
  • Slide a bolt into the rail guide so the triangular tab fits into the screw head. Fix in place with a nut.
  • Remove the supports from gear 1 and fit a nut into the depressions on both sides. Altogether, fit these into the gap in the front of the body, lining up the nuts with the hole in the body.
  • Slide the rail guide onto the rails, with the bolt fitting through the hole to gear 1.
  • Screw the bolt through the gear by turning the gear to the right.
  • Once it's protruding, screw the plunger head onto the bolt.
  • Fit gear 2 onto the stepper motor.
  • Slot the stepper motor into the side of the body, optionally fixing with screws.
  • Remove the plunger from your syringe and put the rubber bit onto the extruder's plunger. Fit the syringe into the extruder!

This is a pair of almost identical casings for throwies which fit together in several different ways and allow easy access to the LEDs so that it is easier to replace any dead battery. This was designed in tinkercad and printed using a MakerBot. I used 6x3h,10d=m, 2x6.5d,1m=m, Li3V coin cell 5mm LED

Once you download the STLs and print out the pieces glue some magnets into the holes left for them (I used 6 magnets with a diameter of 10mm and  a height of 3mm and for the smaller magnet holes I used 2 magnets with a diameter of 6.5mm and a height of 1mm) be very careful about which side you glue the magnets down on and make sure before you glue in the magnets that the magnets on the two pieces attract each other. Once the magnets have been glued put a LED taped to a coin battery into the two slots (I used a two Lithium 3V coin cells for batteries with two 5mm LEDs)

title: **Très spécifique** Pièce en plastique pour fenêtre / **Very specific** plastic bit for windows

description.text:
FR: Cette pièce sert à tenir entrouverte les fenêtres à double battant qui se trouvent chez ma mère et éviter que le vent ne les fasse se balader quand on aère. La poignée du premier battant viens se glisser dans cette pièce, mais ça fait plus de 10 ans que les châssis sont installés, l'âge et quelques mauvais traitements en ont abimé une qui à été coupée en deux. Donc fenêtre soit ouverte totalement, soit fermée. Pour l'anecdote, ma sœur a été voir en magasin (spécialisé) pour savoir si la pièce pouvait être commandée, la seule réponse qu'on lui a donné était d'acheter de nouvelles fenêtres... J'ai pris comme modèle la moins abimées des pièces disponibles sur les autres fenêtres de la maison, 1h30 de taf et le tour est joué. 
Si jamais un jour quelqu'un sur cette terre a besoin de cette pièce, j'invoque tous les dieux et les esprits de la nature, nouveaux et anciens, pour qu'il tombe sur cette page. 
EN: This piece is used to keep ajar the windows at my moms house and avoid them to swing with the wind. The handle of one windows comme slide in these piece, but the frame have more than 10 years, age and few bad treatments have damaged one of them which have been cut in half. So, the windows could only be opened or closed. For the anecdote, my sister have gone to a (specialized) store to see if the piece could be ordered, the only answer given to her was to buy new windows. I've taken the less damaged of the remaining pieces available on the other windows of the house, 1h30 of work later the job was done.
If one day someone on this earth need this piece, i invoke all the gods and spirits of the nature, ancient and new, to make him come on this page.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/21tKWeP4QLr

This is a redesign of the Motorcycle throttle lock by toofuu and my previous throttle lock.
It has a hinge and does not need to be inserted from the end of the grip, which makes it compatible with handguards, and generally easier to put on/off even on standard grips. The hinged body is printed in one piece, use patience and an xacto knife to free up the hinge. The thumbscrew is mounted on the top of the throttle lock, not in the slot in the body. The body and thumbscrew have detents to limit slip (these might wear out, maybe add a small o-ring).
Use one stainless steel M4 bolt (30-35mm) and a standard nut. The design can be improved. Any feedback is appreciated. IMPORTANT SAFETY WARNING: make sure that the head of the bolt fits in the hexagonal recess in the bottom rail of the hinge, where the brake lever slides. It is dangerous to have any protrusion that might interfere with the brake lever operation. Before you try the throttle lock on the road, familiarize yourself with its operation, adjust the screw tension, make sure nothing interferes with the normal operation of your controls, etc. you don't want to find out something is not working right during a panic brake.... Ride safe!

Increased hinge play to make printing easier.
Redesigned the thumbscrew.
Scaled up slighly. Three versions of the main body are available, with or without small tabs to aid engagement/disengagement of the throttle lock (thanks dmai for the idea).

description.text:
There's always room on Thingiverse for another 3D printed box!
This was an experiment in achieving a 'real' wood effect using ColorFabb Woodfill filament.
ColorFabb filament is great stuff, but it didn't give me the 'real' wood surface finish i was looking for. So i designed and modelled this simple little chest, spending a lot of time creating the wood grain texture onto all surfaces and faux Dovetail joints. And to complete, i just had to add some hinges and a latch. Printed in ColourFabb Woodfill http://colorfabb.com/woodfill-fine
and
Faberdashery Robot Siver PLA http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/robot-silver/ The file sizes are quite large - sorry about that, but the wood texture surface effect needed a high model poly-count to achieve the detail. I may see if can optimise those. Enjoy! UPDATE: 210416
http://www.thingiverse.com/pitcherj/about reported some errors in a couple of the files - thanks for the heads up! Hopefully fixed now. ChestBaseFrame_v2.stl
ChestLidFrame_v2.stl

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Low for the chest High for the hinges and latch

Infill:

35%

Notes: I printed all parts of the Chest with a 0.8mm nozzle @ 0.4mm layer height I printed the hinges and latch with a 0.25 nozzle @ 0.1mm layer height The ChestLid file prints on its end, so i added a '10 walled Brim' to give it support whilst printing. All other parts printed without support or raft.
Use a good plastic/wood glue to fix all parts together

The file sizes are quite large - sorry about that, but the wood texture surface effect needed a high model poly-count to achieve the detail. I may see if can optimise those.
All files sliced and printed without issue.

description.text: This is an identical copy of the His and Her Owls that is quite popular on the thingiverse. However, the STL file supplied for that model does not work with MakerWare due to "inverted normals" on the female owl, meaning MakerWare was interpretting it as "inside-out" and couldn't render it. I was able to fix the problem in Blender and re-export it properly. I successfully loaded it in MakerWare and printed it without issue on my MBot Cube II.

The right owl has inverted normals -- they're all facing inwards. So each "outer" surface of the female owl is interpretted as an interior surface. This is why it shows up weird in MakerWare (it's displaying the interior of an object, as if it was inside-out), and it doesn't print properly because it's not sure what to do.  [Theoretically, shouldn't it print a cube with an owl-shaped hole in it? :) ]  
I loaded the STL file in Blender and was able to verify this is the case. All I had to do was select all the faces of the right owl (switch to front-facing (numpad-1), orthographic view (numpad-5), and then 'b' for box select). Then on the left-menu there is a button for "Normals -> Flip Direction".  That's all I did before re-exporting to STL.   
I had similar problems with other models that I made in Blender: I created some surfaces/objects, but some of the normals were facing the wrong way and MakerWare freaked out and printed garbage. If you are making a model in Blender, you can switch to edit mode, open the properties menu ("N" key), select the "Normals->Show Face" button, and then set the size to 1.0 or higher. Any outer surface of your model should have the blue normal vector extending outwards into open air, not into the model.

description.text:
Update: Cleaned the script up a little. I have learned much more since the original version of the script was uploaded.  
Since the LED matrix holders I have found so far aren't parametric, or won't fit standard pitch veroboard, I made my own in OpenSCAD. You can fully customize the height of the case, number of rows and columns, LED size, grid size, grid spacing and thickness of the bottom plate and outer walls.  
Sample files for the most commonly used formats provided: 5x7 and 8x8 for 3mm and 5mm LEDs.  
When setting the final height correctly, it can also be used as a jig for making LED cubes :-)  
This is my first parametric thing I have uploaded together with the script, so please don't judge me too hard.
